description: Beal V-Groove friction system provides controlled braking across a wide range of rope diameters. The straight edge decreases rope wear, and each device has an individual serial number for traceability.
pros: V-Groove friction adapts to rope diameter

description: The Air Force 3 adds guide mode to Beal V-Groove design, allowing belaying one or two followers from above. A small release hole makes it easy to lower under tension. Optimized for modern thin ropes.
cons: Less widely available than Reverso or ATC Guide

description: Beal's assisted-braking device with anti-panic function. The Birdie offers smooth lowering and reliable braking in a design that's easier to learn than the GriGri for some climbers.

The original Air Traffic Controller — the device that defined the modern tube belay device category. Simple, lightweight, and reliable with a wide rope range. No frills, no guide mode, just a proven design that has been trusted by millions of climbers since 1993.

A thin-rope specialist tube device designed for alpine climbing with half and twin ropes. At just 74g, the ATC-Alpine Guide is one of the lightest belay devices with guide mode, making it ideal for weight-conscious alpinists. Handles ropes as thin as 6.9mm.

The most versatile belay device available. The ATC Guide does everything — lead belay, top belay, guide mode for belaying a second from above, single and double rope rappel. Its simplicity is its strength: no moving parts, works with virtually any rope, and weighs under 90g. The go-to device for multi-pitch climbing, trad, and alpine where versatility trumps assisted braking.
cons: No assisted braking when lead belaying
Requires constant vigilance on brake hand
Lowering in guide mode can be tricky
Less comfortable for long projecting sessions

description: A single-rope passive assisted braking device that uses geometry to pinch the rope between device and carabiner during a fall. Ultra-lightweight at 94g, the ATC-Pilot offers brake assistance in a familiar tube-style package — perfect for gym and single-pitch cragging.
cons: Less braking power than cam devices

description: The enhanced version of the classic ATC with grooved friction channels on one side for extra braking power. Flip it over for a smoother, lower-friction feed when conditions require it. No guide mode, so it's not ideal as a primary multi-pitch device, but its simplicity, double rope compatibility, and unbeatable price make it a perfect starter device or reliable backup.

The Black Diamond Super 8 is a modern figure-eight style device with ears to prevent girth hitching. Dual friction modes and compatibility with ropes from 8.1–11mm make it versatile for rappelling and rescue.
pros: Great for SAR and rescue teams
cons: Less friction control than tubes for lead belaying

description: CAMP's contender against the GriGri, with an anti-panic feature baked in. The Matik uses a cam mechanism similar to the GriGri but adds a spring-loaded anti-panic handle that re-engages the cam if the lever is opened too far — similar to the GriGri+ but in a different form factor. Lighter than the GriGri+ and cheaper, making it an attractive alternative for climbers wanting assisted braking with extra safety.
pros: Anti-panic at a lower price than GriGri+
cons: Less smooth slack feeding than GriGri
No guide mode or double rope rappel

description: The CAMP Shell is an ultralight guide-mode belay device at just 60g. Unique shell-shaped design with asymmetric V-grooves provides different friction levels for lead vs top-rope belaying. Guide mode allows belaying one or two seconds from an anchor.

The Swiss Army knife of belay devices. The Alpine Up offers assisted braking in lead mode, guide mode for multi-pitch, and standard rappel — all in a 160g package. One of the most versatile devices on the market.
pros: Works with single and half ropes
cons: Braking not as positive as cam devices
Can be fiddly with thin ropes

description: A GriGri alternative with a twist: the Click Up's anti-panic function locks the rope if the handle is pulled too hard. Great for nervous beginners and gym climbing.

The upgraded Click Up+ adds an anti-panic system to the popular Click Up design. Uses a special carabiner (included) that enables the braking geometry. If the belayer panics and pulls the handle too far, the device re-engages the brake automatically.

One of the lightest tube-style belay devices on the market at just 45g. The Mantis is DMM's minimalist tube device — simple, reliable, and extremely lightweight. Ideal as a backup device or for weight-conscious climbers.

DMM's answer to the lowering-in-guide-mode problem. The Pivot features a unique pivot mechanism that makes lowering a second in guide mode dramatically easier than competing devices. Where the ATC Guide and Reverso require workarounds to release an auto-blocked climber, the Pivot's design allows a controlled lower with a simple lever motion. A favorite among UK trad climbers.
pros: Unique pivot mechanism for smooth release

description: The Giga Jul extends the Mega Jul concept with wider rope compatibility down to 7.1mm twins and a switchable assisted/manual braking mode. The toggle lets you choose between assisted braking for lead belaying and free-running mode for smoother rope feeding. Accepts the widest rope diameter range of any brake-assist device, making it uniquely suited for teams using half or twin ropes on alpine routes.
pros: Handles twin ropes better than any rival
cons: More friction in auto-block than competitors
Learning curve steeper than single-mode devices

description: Edelrid's entry-level passive assisted braking device with geometry that blocks the rope during a fall. Easier rope payout than the Mega Jul thanks to optimized slot geometry. A great choice for gym climbing and indoor/outdoor single-pitch use.
pros: Easy rope payout for lead belaying

description: The Swiss Army knife of belay devices. The Mega Jul combines passive assisted braking with guide mode and double rope capability in an ultralight 65g steel package — something no other device achieves. Thinner than a phone and weighing 61% less than a GriGri, it handles everything from lead belaying to double-rope rappelling. The tradeoff: a steep learning curve and technique-dependent braking.
pros: Lightest assisted braking with guide mode
Full rope type compatibility with brake assist

description: The Edelrid Micro Jul is a tiny stainless-steel passive assisted-braking device designed for thin ropes from 6.9–8.9mm. Originally created to pair with the groundbreaking 6.9mm Flycatcher rope, it features guide mode for belaying seconds and can also be used for rappelling. The assisted braking engages through device geometry — no moving parts.
cons: Not for thick single ropes above 8.9mm
Requires specific technique for smooth feeding
Steep learning curve compared to tubes

description: The Edelrid Nano Jul is a stainless-steel tube-style guide device optimized for thin half and twin ropes from 7.1–8.9mm. Its guide mode allows belaying one or two followers from above on multi-pitch routes. Built for durability with no moving parts.

Edelrid's newest cam-assisted device with a revolutionary closure system that clips directly to the belay loop — no separate carabiner needed. This eliminates the risk of cross-loading or carabiner twist during falls. Features anti-panic on the lowering handle and a clean industrial design. Positioned as a direct GriGri competitor with the added safety of integrated attachment.
pros: Integrated belay loop attachment — no carabiner needed
cons: New design — limited field testing data

description: Grivel lightest tube belay device at just 64g. A simple, no-frills design with V-grooves for controlled braking on a wide range of rope diameters from 7.3–11mm.

The Grivel Master Pro is a lightweight guide-mode belay device with cooling holes for heat dissipation and horns for extra friction with thin ropes. Works as a self-locking plate for belaying seconds from above.
cons: Plain aluminum wears faster than steel

description: The Grivel Scream is an ultralight specialist tube device designed exclusively for thin ropes from 5–8mm. Perfect for alpine and ice climbing where every gram counts and half/twin ropes are standard.
pros: Great for ice and mixed climbing

description: Designed for mountain guides, the Grivel Shuttle features an optimized guide-mode geometry that makes pulling up rope easier on multi-pitch routes, saving energy for the actual climbing.
pros: Easy rope pulling in guide mode
cons: Slightly heavy at 85g for a tube device

description: A budget-friendly Italian-made plate device with guide mode capability. The Gi-Gi handles ropes from 8mm all the way up to 13mm, making it one of the most accommodating belay devices. Perfect as a lightweight guide-mode device at an unbeatable price.

A compact and lightweight active assisted braking device that rivals the GriGri at a lower price. The Lifeguard uses a cam mechanism for reliable brake assistance. Hot forged aircraft-grade aluminum and stainless steel construction ensures durability.
cons: Handle can override cam in full throttle

description: The Safeguard is the springless version of Mad Rock Lifeguard. Without the internal spring, the cam is always on — any force from the climber side blocks the rope. Designed primarily for rescue and rigging rather than lead climbing.
Mammut's ultralight tube device with guide mode. At just 57g it's perfect for weight-conscious alpinists who need a reliable device for half and twin ropes on long routes.

Mammut's innovative and robust tube-style belay device with V-shaped grooves and abrasion-resistant steel inserts. At just 80g, it allows guide-mode belaying of one or two seconds independently. The steel insert prevents overheating during long rappels.
pros: Steel inserts prevent wear and overheating
cons: Steel adds slight weight vs pure aluminum

description: Mammut's passive assisted braking device — a lightweight alternative to mechanical cam devices. The Smart 2.0 uses a simple pinching mechanism between the device body and carabiner to provide braking assistance during falls. Easy to learn, lightweight at 75g, and significantly cheaper than the GriGri. Ideal for gym climbers and beginners who want extra security without the complexity of a cam device.
cons: Single rope only, no guide mode
Higher friction in guide mode testing

description: The alpine version of Mammut's popular Smart 2.0, adding guide mode and two rope slots for multi-pitch climbing with half ropes. Combines passive brake assistance with tube-device versatility. Handles ropes from 7.5mm for alpine and ice climbing.
pros: Wide rope range for alpine use
cons: Assisted braking not as strong as cam

description: The Metolius BRD (Belay/Rappel Device) is a CNC-machined tubular device with engineered friction channels and cooling fins for heat dissipation during long lowers and rappels. A friction horn on the cable end provides extra stopping power when needed.
pros: Extra friction horn for controlled lowers

description: A Czech-made passive-assisted tube device from Ocun with guide mode. The Hawk uses geometry to provide assisted braking while maintaining tube-device versatility. Very light at 72g with guide mode — a great all-rounder for multi-pitch climbing.
cons: Assisted braking less powerful than cam devices

description: The gold standard of assisted braking belay devices. The GriGri's cam-assisted blocking provides reliable fall arrest while maintaining smooth rope feeding for experienced belayers. Updated version handles ropes down to 8.5mm with improved cam engagement and 3:1 mechanical advantage for comfortable lowering. The most popular belay device at any crag worldwide.
pros: Excellent for projecting and long belays
cons: Single rope only — no rappel on doubled rope
Can lock up when feeding slack quickly

description: The safety-enhanced version of the GriGri with additional features for guides and newer climbers. Anti-panic handle automatically re-engages the cam if the lever is opened too far during lowering. Lead/top-rope toggle adjusts cam spring tension — tighter in top-rope mode for extra security. 3:1 mechanical advantage makes it ideal for weight mismatches and big wall hauling.

The next evolution in assisted braking. The Neox features an integrated wheel that eliminates the biggest complaint about the GriGri — premature cam engagement when feeding slack. The wheel spins freely during normal rope feeding but stops and engages the cam during falls. Universally praised as a game-changer for lead belaying, offering ATC-smooth slack feeding with GriGri-level fall arrest.
cons: Newer design — less field track record
Single rope only — no double strand rappel

description: Petzl's ultralight tube device with guide mode. At just 59g, the Reverso is one of the lightest full-featured tube devices available, making it the alpinist's choice. Works with single, half, and twin ropes for complete versatility. Smooth rappelling characteristics make it a favorite for long multi-pitch descents. The asymmetric shape provides two friction levels depending on orientation.
cons: Lowering in guide mode requires technique
Thin walls wear faster on sharp edges
Less braking friction than ATC Guide

description: Petzl's ultralight and compact tubular belay device — the lightest in the Petzl belay lineup at just 55g. A simple, reliable tube device for gym and outdoor climbing. Handles all rope types from 6.9mm to 11mm, making it versatile for any climbing style.
cons: Requires solid technique for lead belay

description: Salewa's ergonomic assisted-braking device. The Ergo's cam mechanism provides reliable braking while the handle design keeps your hand in the correct position. A good alternative for Salewa loyalists.
cons: Brand less established in belay devices

description: The Singing Rock Buddy is an ultra-lightweight tube belay device at just 54g. Smooth rope handling and effective heat dissipation make it a great budget option for gym and crag climbing.
pros: Only 54g — one of the lightest tubes

description: The Singing Rock Shuttle features guide mode with self-locking function for belaying seconds. V-grooves provide high friction, and an eye-hole allows releasing the self-lock under tension. Can simultaneously belay two climbers.
The Trango Aries is a hot-forged 7075 aluminum guide-mode device with dual V channels for controlled braking. Wide rope range from 7.5–11mm makes it versatile for all climbing styles.
cons: Less well-known than Reverso or ATC Guide

description: The Trango Cinch is a cam-assisted belay device with a straightforward design for single ropes. Its spring-loaded cam locks automatically when loaded, and the smooth lowering lever provides controlled descents. Best suited for gym and sport climbing with thicker ropes.
A time-honored tube design with a pivoting center pin that allows flipping for customizable friction. V-shaped rope channels and tapered geometry provide versatile braking control.
cons: Narrower rope range than modern tubes

description: Trango's GriGri competitor with anti-panic and lead/TR mode switch. The Vergo's dual-mode design lets you optimize braking for lead or top-rope. A strong choice for gym and sport climbing.

A lightweight tube device with guide mode from Wild Country. At 77g, the Pro Guide Lite is one of the lightest devices with auto-block functionality for multi-pitch climbing. Excellent value for a versatile, no-frills belay/rappel device.
The panic-proof belay device. The Revo's bi-directional locking mechanism stops the rope in ANY scenario — whether you grip too hard or let go entirely. The safest assisted device on the market.
pros: Bi-directional locking — works if you grip or release
